description: The intent of the Managing across the Lifecycle (MALC) qualification is to give candidates the skills to support an organization’s service delivery by bridging the service lifecycle stages. The qualification demonstrates that candidates have learned the value of one combined service management practice as opposed to separate subject areas. ITIL processes and practices, as learned from the lifecycle and capability streams of the intermediate certificates, are put into a context of delivering this value.
descriptionMD: ** Look for our partner PassionIT Group's information [HERE](https://itprotv-notes-bucket.s3.amazonaws.com/ITIL_OVERVIEW.zip)  Codes for offers are available to members and in the download in the second episode** The intent of the Managing across the Lifecycle (MALC) qualification is to give candidates the skills to support an organization’s service delivery by bridging the service lifecycle stages. The qualification demonstrates that candidates have learned the value of one combined service management practice as opposed to separate subject areas. ITIL processes and practices, as learned from the lifecycle and capability streams of the intermediate certificates, are put into a context of delivering this value. For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please [contact PassionIT Group](mailto:info@passionitgroup.com).
name: Accredited ITIL Expert - MALC
subtitle: Managing Across the Lifecycle

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a general lay of the land for the ITProTV MALC course.
episodes.title: Logistics, Setup and Expectations
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.200
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.200 --> 00:00:03.731
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.731 --> 00:00:07.926
[CROSSTALK].

4
00:00:07.926 --> 00:00:09.940
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:09.940 --> 00:00:13.590
>> Hello again, and thank you for

6
00:00:13.590 --> 00:00:17.440
choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:17.440 --> 00:00:19.450
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

8
00:00:19.450 --> 00:00:24.110
Very excited to be your host for
ITIL, managing across the life cycle.

9
00:00:24.110 --> 00:00:26.738
And we'll be diving into logistics,

10
00:00:26.738 --> 00:00:30.606
setup and expectations with
our very own Terry Decker.

11
00:00:30.606 --> 00:00:31.524
And he's right there.

12
00:00:31.524 --> 00:00:33.750
[LAUGH]
>> Yup happy to be here Zach.

13
00:00:33.750 --> 00:00:37.689
As usual we're going to setup
this course by talking about

14
00:00:38.690 --> 00:00:39.990
the basic logistics of things.

15
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:42.190
Work to orient yourself
towards the class files,

16
00:00:42.190 --> 00:00:45.800
what you expect from the exam,
what do you expect out of the course?

17
00:00:45.800 --> 00:00:48.510
And without further adieu,
let's just kind of dive in here.

18
00:00:48.510 --> 00:00:53.910
This is the Capstone course for
all of the ITIL curriculum.

19
00:00:53.910 --> 00:00:59.490
It's the final stage, if you will, before
you get to the ITIL expert credential.

20
00:00:59.490 --> 00:01:03.934
So, the prerequisite before you can
take this exam and get credit for

21
00:01:03.934 --> 00:01:06.012
the exam are 17 credit hours.

22
00:01:06.012 --> 00:01:07.470
We'll get to that a little bit later.

23
00:01:07.470 --> 00:01:10.560
And you see,
we're moving up the Blooms taxonomy scale.

24
00:01:10.560 --> 00:01:15.520
You have to apply your knowledge a little
bit more expertly as the phrase goes.

25
00:01:15.520 --> 00:01:20.060
So, when we did foundations,
we were at the lower end of this.

26
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:24.080
We need to remember things and
be able to understand some concepts.

27
00:01:24.080 --> 00:01:29.932
The intermediate level exams that you've
taken dealt with applying knowledge.

28
00:01:29.932 --> 00:01:34.350
And making sure that you could analyze
a given situation based on a scenario.

29
00:01:34.350 --> 00:01:38.500
Well, what we're doing here in the MALC
exam is taking it a little bit higher and

30
00:01:38.500 --> 00:01:41.140
looking at synthesizing, if you will.

31
00:01:41.140 --> 00:01:45.350
Evaluating a situation and
creating new knowledge, if you will,

32
00:01:45.350 --> 00:01:46.850
applying it effectively.

33
00:01:46.850 --> 00:01:50.139
And primarily that's done
through this case study.

34
00:01:50.139 --> 00:01:51.299
Not just scenarios but

35
00:01:51.299 --> 00:01:55.220
a full blown case study where you get
very familiar with this organization.

36
00:01:55.220 --> 00:01:58.009
It's a financial services organization.

37
00:01:58.009 --> 00:02:03.910
It's a challenging exam but it's also
a rewarding exam in that once passed,

38
00:02:03.910 --> 00:02:07.760
you get a very special
credential called ITIL expert.

39
00:02:07.760 --> 00:02:10.170
>> And everybody wants to be
an ITIL expert I would think.

40
00:02:10.170 --> 00:02:10.780
>> Yeah, that's right.

41
00:02:10.780 --> 00:02:12.400
>> Who wants to get in ITIL of course.

42
00:02:12.400 --> 00:02:13.360
>> That's right.
>> Yeah..

43
00:02:13.360 --> 00:02:17.003
>> So as we've done with the intermediate
level exams and courses.

44
00:02:17.003 --> 00:02:20.482
There certainly are gonna be
my presentation of theory and

45
00:02:20.482 --> 00:02:24.810
lecture approach giving real
world examples to these concepts.

46
00:02:24.810 --> 00:02:27.690
The primary difference is
we approach marker however

47
00:02:27.690 --> 00:02:30.750
is that we are not really
bringing in new information.

48
00:02:30.750 --> 00:02:34.220
It's really just going to be how
we can synthesize this information

49
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:35.350
towards some common goal.

50
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:39.912
So a little bit less
importance is my lecture.

51
00:02:39.912 --> 00:02:43.910
It's gonna be a high expectation
that you're gonna be diving

52
00:02:43.910 --> 00:02:47.170
into the practice exams,
the mock tests if you will.

53
00:02:47.170 --> 00:02:51.070
You're gonna be doing some exercises
in getting real familiar with this

54
00:02:51.070 --> 00:02:52.250
case study.

55
00:02:52.250 --> 00:02:56.970
The good news is, is this case study that
we use throughout this portion of the exam

56
00:02:56.970 --> 00:03:01.440
prep, is the exact same case study
you'll get on the real exam.

57
00:03:01.440 --> 00:03:02.982
So, you can memorize this thing.

58
00:03:02.982 --> 00:03:08.550
You'll know this company inside out
before you even go o take the exam.

59
00:03:08.550 --> 00:03:13.030
And then of course, the scenarios based on
this case study, this company if you will,

60
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:19.210
that tease out some more details that you
have to approach in the actual questions.

61
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:20.670
>> Okay.
>> So a lot of good information for

62
00:03:20.670 --> 00:03:23.130
you to sink your teeth
into in this course.

63
00:03:25.400 --> 00:03:28.483
All this material is owned and
operated by AXELOS,

64
00:03:28.483 --> 00:03:33.011
the ones that own the copyright material,
it's called ITIL curriculum.

65
00:03:33.011 --> 00:03:37.424
A brief history, as you know ITIL
has been around since the late 80's.

66
00:03:37.424 --> 00:03:40.326
It's gone through some
upgrades over the years.

67
00:03:40.326 --> 00:03:42.861
We're at now at version three since 2011.

68
00:03:42.861 --> 00:03:48.110
The only significant update to
the ITIL material since 2011 has been

69
00:03:48.110 --> 00:03:53.371
the addition of the ITIL practitioner
course that came out last spring.

70
00:03:53.371 --> 00:03:57.392
And that course helps answer the question,

71
00:03:57.392 --> 00:04:03.380
how would I go about answering
the question about adopting ITIL.

72
00:04:03.380 --> 00:04:06.400
You remember the five
stages of the life cycle?

73
00:04:06.400 --> 00:04:08.400
Again, no new information here.

74
00:04:08.400 --> 00:04:10.170
I'm going to be, certainly,

75
00:04:10.170 --> 00:04:14.140
touching on the life cycle stages, and
how they integrate with each other.

76
00:04:15.140 --> 00:04:19.470
Those inner points of integration,
managing across the life cycle

77
00:04:19.470 --> 00:04:23.520
necessarily means you're gonna be
looking at this at a 5,000-foot view.

78
00:04:23.520 --> 00:04:29.380
Holistically, looking at an organizational
challenges from a strategic point of view.

79
00:04:29.380 --> 00:04:31.160
So it's not just service strategy.

80
00:04:31.160 --> 00:04:33.850
It's looking at IT service management

81
00:04:33.850 --> 00:04:39.000
through the lens of Strategic
application and strategic analysis.

82
00:04:39.000 --> 00:04:40.960
So again, kinda challenging, but

83
00:04:40.960 --> 00:04:45.390
also quite rewarding cuz it gives
you that nice big view of ITIL.

84
00:04:47.170 --> 00:04:50.240
So, The Qualification Scheme.

85
00:04:50.240 --> 00:04:54.490
All these is all maintained
in accredited status

86
00:04:54.490 --> 00:04:58.490
from AXELOS on through
the exam institutes.

87
00:04:58.490 --> 00:05:02.555
Exam institutes then accredit
training organization,

88
00:05:02.555 --> 00:05:08.295
I'm here representing PassionIT Group,
an accredited training organization.

89
00:05:08.295 --> 00:05:11.115
They go through the rigors
of designing the curriculum

90
00:05:11.115 --> 00:05:14.895
according to the syllabus as
published by the exam institutes.

91
00:05:14.895 --> 00:05:19.175
They are audited for compliance with
that syllabus and also audited for

92
00:05:19.175 --> 00:05:20.505
compliance in delivery.

93
00:05:20.505 --> 00:05:25.350
So that gives the PassionIT
group the accreditation

94
00:05:25.350 --> 00:05:29.665
to send me as an accredited trainer
to deliver this for ITProTV.

95
00:05:31.480 --> 00:05:36.140
Obviously, all this is works together
to mean that there's quality control

96
00:05:36.140 --> 00:05:38.510
throughout the system through the exams,

97
00:05:38.510 --> 00:05:42.679
through the curriculum development,
mapping back to a specific syllabus.

98
00:05:43.880 --> 00:05:44.650
>> Perfect.

99
00:05:44.650 --> 00:05:45.600
>> Yup.

100
00:05:45.600 --> 00:05:49.675
Now, it kinda looks like a house here,
the house that ITIL built.

101
00:05:49.675 --> 00:05:52.730
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you have a look near the bottom of

102
00:05:52.730 --> 00:05:54.110
this, you've got Foundation, of course.

103
00:05:54.110 --> 00:05:56.300
That's where you would expect
to see the foundation.

104
00:05:56.300 --> 00:05:57.500
It's the bottom of the house.

105
00:05:57.500 --> 00:05:58.620
That is a prerequisite.

106
00:05:58.620 --> 00:06:00.170
You must have foundation.

107
00:06:00.170 --> 00:06:02.840
As one of your sets of credits.

108
00:06:02.840 --> 00:06:03.940
You get two credits for that.

109
00:06:03.940 --> 00:06:06.890
You'll see ITIL Practitioner
can get you three credits.

110
00:06:06.890 --> 00:06:11.950
As you go up through these courses,
you get different degrees of credits.

111
00:06:11.950 --> 00:06:15.720
So on the Capability Module side here,
you'll see Service Offerings and

112
00:06:15.720 --> 00:06:19.300
Agreements, Release, Control and
Validation, Planning, Protection and

113
00:06:19.300 --> 00:06:21.910
Optimization, Operational Support and
Analysis.

114
00:06:21.910 --> 00:06:26.790
Those Capability Modules
give you four credits each.

115
00:06:26.790 --> 00:06:28.850
All available on ITProTV, by the way.

116
00:06:28.850 --> 00:06:31.320
>> Right, and we have the sample
paper reviews as well that we did.

117
00:06:31.320 --> 00:06:32.090
>> That's right.

118
00:06:32.090 --> 00:06:37.620
So again,
it's expectation before you take mount

119
00:06:37.620 --> 00:06:40.850
you've collected 17 credits.

120
00:06:42.730 --> 00:06:46.450
However you get those credits two
of them must be foundation, and

121
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:48.190
then you just gotta go get 15 more.

122
00:06:48.190 --> 00:06:52.010
Do you take these four capability ones,
which is 16 a little overkill?

123
00:06:52.010 --> 00:06:55.470
Do you take five life cycle ones,
>> Right.

124
00:06:55.470 --> 00:06:56.480
>> To get those?

125
00:06:56.480 --> 00:07:02.980
When you have a total of 17,
You are eligible to take the MALC exam.

126
00:07:02.980 --> 00:07:06.520
And with the MALC exam,
successful passing the MALC exam,

127
00:07:06.520 --> 00:07:09.430
gives you five credits, that totals 22.

128
00:07:09.430 --> 00:07:13.240
Those 22 credits get you that magic
credential called ITIL expert.

129
00:07:14.240 --> 00:07:18.320
To be an accredited trainer you
must hold the expert credential.

130
00:07:18.320 --> 00:07:22.430
So, if you're in an accredited training
class you know that your instructor has

131
00:07:22.430 --> 00:07:25.760
gone through the accredited
training up to the expert level.

132
00:07:26.910 --> 00:07:30.710
Now, in my particular case I've
happened to take both sides of these.

133
00:07:30.710 --> 00:07:32.470
I've taken all the lifecycle ones.

134
00:07:32.470 --> 00:07:33.780
I've taken all the capability ones.

135
00:07:33.780 --> 00:07:35.680
I've also had practitioner and foundation.

136
00:07:36.690 --> 00:07:40.310
And I bring that knowledge
to the lecture for MALC.

137
00:07:41.490 --> 00:07:42.580
You need to do that too.

138
00:07:42.580 --> 00:07:45.280
You've gone on some path, to get here.

139
00:07:45.280 --> 00:07:48.350
Maybe you've taken life cycle modules.

140
00:07:48.350 --> 00:07:50.070
Maybe you've taken some
capability modules.

141
00:07:50.070 --> 00:07:52.240
Maybe you've mixed and matched them,
which is totally fine.

142
00:07:53.280 --> 00:07:55.950
But you're gonna be bringing
that knowledge to this course.

143
00:07:55.950 --> 00:07:57.244
And more importantly,

144
00:07:57.244 --> 00:08:00.620
holistically bringing that same
knowledge to the MALC exam.

145
00:08:00.620 --> 00:08:05.482
As I mentioned before MALC
brings no new information.

146
00:08:05.482 --> 00:08:09.260
It's gonna be the trick of the trade
here is going to be how we use this

147
00:08:09.260 --> 00:08:13.730
information in some sort of synthesis,
creating knowledge,

148
00:08:13.730 --> 00:08:16.280
creating application for this knowledge.

149
00:08:17.330 --> 00:08:18.519
So just a little bit step further.

150
00:08:20.940 --> 00:08:22.530
Here they are again played out.

151
00:08:22.530 --> 00:08:24.920
The ITIL foundations through
the life cycle modules.

152
00:08:24.920 --> 00:08:29.140
One of the differences between the life
cycle modules and the capability modules

153
00:08:29.140 --> 00:08:35.390
is the life cycle modules are one to one
relationship to the core publications.

154
00:08:35.390 --> 00:08:38.300
What I mean by that is there's
a course called service strategy.

155
00:08:38.300 --> 00:08:40.860
There's a core publication
called service strategy.

156
00:08:40.860 --> 00:08:43.410
There's a course called
service transition.

157
00:08:43.410 --> 00:08:44.940
There's a book called service transition.

158
00:08:44.940 --> 00:08:48.670
So one to one relationship there.

159
00:08:48.670 --> 00:08:53.780
The capability modules are based
on a blend of the core books.

160
00:08:53.780 --> 00:08:58.547
As an example, service offering agreements
takes some from service strategy and

161
00:08:58.547 --> 00:09:00.146
some from service design.

162
00:09:00.146 --> 00:09:04.200
And mixes them into a practical approach.

163
00:09:04.200 --> 00:09:05.630
So, it's more like doing.

164
00:09:05.630 --> 00:09:07.730
You get a bit more credit for
those as well.

165
00:09:07.730 --> 00:09:11.590
And a little bit deeper dive
into the activities involved

166
00:09:11.590 --> 00:09:13.839
in those specific processes
that are being discussed.

167
00:09:15.090 --> 00:09:17.340
MALC again takes that a step further.

168
00:09:17.340 --> 00:09:21.180
So, if you're taking a Service Strategy
Exam, or you're taking a Service Offerings

169
00:09:21.180 --> 00:09:25.690
and Agreement Exam,
you kinda know the boundaries of the exam.

170
00:09:25.690 --> 00:09:29.600
It's just that subject
matter you just took.

171
00:09:29.600 --> 00:09:33.130
MALC is gonna be a bit more challenging
in that the subject matter is

172
00:09:33.130 --> 00:09:35.470
all five books all the time.

173
00:09:35.470 --> 00:09:39.060
And how they blend together and how
they're distinguishing from each other.

174
00:09:39.060 --> 00:09:42.695
So that makes MALC challenging but,
again, it also makes it rewarding.

175
00:09:42.695 --> 00:09:46.430
Because you're getting to this practical
sense of strategically looking

176
00:09:46.430 --> 00:09:49.120
at ITIL as a strategic asset.

177
00:09:49.120 --> 00:09:51.700
And that's really what we're
trying to position MALC for.

178
00:09:51.700 --> 00:09:52.200
>> Perfect.

179
00:09:53.470 --> 00:09:56.341
>> So
the exam itself is virtually the same as

180
00:09:56.341 --> 00:09:59.384
the intermediates you've already taken.

181
00:09:59.384 --> 00:10:01.940
Except there's ten questions and
not eight.

182
00:10:01.940 --> 00:10:04.680
And one big difference is
there's this case study.

183
00:10:04.680 --> 00:10:06.150
It's about seven pages long.

184
00:10:07.360 --> 00:10:12.380
And that case study forms the basis for
eight of the ten questions.

185
00:10:12.380 --> 00:10:16.420
As many as two of the questions can be
away from the topic of the case study.

186
00:10:16.420 --> 00:10:19.480
So you get eight questions
associated with the case study.

187
00:10:19.480 --> 00:10:23.440
Each question has it's own separate
scenario in between the case study and

188
00:10:23.440 --> 00:10:24.400
the question if you will.

189
00:10:25.430 --> 00:10:28.095
So there's that extra
layer of Information.

190
00:10:28.095 --> 00:10:33.045
Certainly the latter episodes when we
start approaching exam preparation.

191
00:10:33.045 --> 00:10:38.595
The latter episodes in this series are
gonna deal with an approach to taking and

192
00:10:38.595 --> 00:10:40.245
mastering this exam technique.

193
00:10:40.245 --> 00:10:43.155
Where you have a case study and
you have the scenario.

194
00:10:43.155 --> 00:10:45.185
So we'll get to that in due time.

195
00:10:45.185 --> 00:10:48.875
You get two hours to take the exam.

196
00:10:48.875 --> 00:10:54.100
So ten questions, 120 minutes,
that's about 12 minutes per question.

197
00:10:54.100 --> 00:10:59.030
You don't wanna be learning the case study
for the first time when you set this exam.

198
00:10:59.030 --> 00:11:02.870
This case study needs to be something
you know very well already.

199
00:11:02.870 --> 00:11:06.790
And again, the good news is the same
case study that's used in this course

200
00:11:06.790 --> 00:11:09.400
is the very same case study
you'll get on the exam.

201
00:11:09.400 --> 00:11:13.320
So there's really no excuse for not
knowing that case study inside and out.

202
00:11:13.320 --> 00:11:14.780
Know it well.

203
00:11:14.780 --> 00:11:17.680
Therefore, you won't be
parsing it while you're

204
00:11:17.680 --> 00:11:19.910
managing your time on the real exam.

205
00:11:19.910 --> 00:11:21.690
Very important there.

206
00:11:21.690 --> 00:11:23.350
You still gotta get a 70%.

207
00:11:23.350 --> 00:11:28.053
That's 35 out of 50, so if you do the math
here, again, you gotta get 70%, that's 35.

208
00:11:28.053 --> 00:11:31.650
There's ten questions.

209
00:11:31.650 --> 00:11:36.490
If you get six three-point answers,
that's 18.

210
00:11:36.490 --> 00:11:38.750
And you got four more to go.

211
00:11:38.750 --> 00:11:41.840
So you can get 20 out of that,
that's 38, all right.

212
00:11:41.840 --> 00:11:47.400
So maybe you can have seven three point
answers to get 21 points with three to go,

213
00:11:47.400 --> 00:11:48.530
gives you the 15.

214
00:11:48.530 --> 00:11:49.930
Kind of do the math there.

215
00:11:49.930 --> 00:11:53.910
So perfection is not required,
70% obviously is not 100%.

216
00:11:53.910 --> 00:11:57.040
But if you were to get a zero answer or

217
00:11:57.040 --> 00:12:00.170
a one answer then you're
margin of error is shrinking.

218
00:12:00.170 --> 00:12:04.080
You gonna have to go find some extra
five point answers along the way.

219
00:12:04.080 --> 00:12:07.740
So as you approach the exam,
a great approach is to get really good and

220
00:12:07.740 --> 00:12:09.180
eliminating the ones and the zeroes.

221
00:12:09.180 --> 00:12:12.980
So that you're always in this little
wheelhouse of choosing between

222
00:12:12.980 --> 00:12:16.460
the best answer and the next best answer.

223
00:12:16.460 --> 00:12:17.670
If you're here,

224
00:12:17.670 --> 00:12:20.810
it's because you've already had some
success on intermediate level exams.

225
00:12:21.890 --> 00:12:25.830
So you know how that row is hoed.

226
00:12:25.830 --> 00:12:27.860
So get your hoe out
>> [LAUGH]

227
00:12:27.860 --> 00:12:28.940
>> And work a little harder.

228
00:12:28.940 --> 00:12:31.738
>> And I'm from Iowa, and
believe me, you need to be hoeing.

229
00:12:31.738 --> 00:12:33.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right.

230
00:12:33.360 --> 00:12:34.930
So that's kinda the lay of the land.

231
00:12:34.930 --> 00:12:36.710
That's the lay of the land,
what you expect.

232
00:12:36.710 --> 00:12:39.720
One other big thing is,
you're own self study is important.

233
00:12:39.720 --> 00:12:43.420
You'll see episode files up above,
there's some up above right now.

234
00:12:43.420 --> 00:12:46.774
As you look at your episode files,
you can download the sample papers.

235
00:12:46.774 --> 00:12:51.120
There are process charts and
various things that can help you study.

236
00:12:51.120 --> 00:12:55.730
And also help you have in front of you
while you're watching these lectures.

237
00:12:55.730 --> 00:12:58.980
It's a good visual reference,
including the course handbook.

238
00:12:58.980 --> 00:13:01.060
Which has the same PowerPoint
as going through here.

239
00:13:01.060 --> 00:13:02.960
You can take notes and whatnot.

240
00:13:02.960 --> 00:13:05.392
So I highly encourage you to
download those materials.

241
00:13:05.392 --> 00:13:09.405
And as you get into each episode,
you'll find additional materials for

242
00:13:09.405 --> 00:13:11.570
knowledge checks and exercises.

243
00:13:11.570 --> 00:13:13.100
I highly encourage you to go there.

244
00:13:13.100 --> 00:13:16.144
And as we go through the episodes,
I'll remind you that they're there and

245
00:13:16.144 --> 00:13:17.316
what the value of those are.

246
00:13:17.316 --> 00:13:21.320
And I look forward to seeing you for
future episodes here.

247
00:13:21.320 --> 00:13:22.150
>> Thank you Terry.

248
00:13:22.150 --> 00:13:26.760
And we're gonna be diving really into this
MALC so, and fortunately its on video.

249
00:13:26.760 --> 00:13:28.610
You can watch it again and
again and again.

250
00:13:28.610 --> 00:13:30.550
So again, thanks again Terry.

251
00:13:30.550 --> 00:13:31.530
>> Glad to be.

252
00:13:31.530 --> 00:13:34.080
>> And thank you for watching ITProTV.

253
00:13:34.080 --> 00:13:37.040
You know a good IT Pro is always learning.

254
00:13:37.040 --> 00:13:37.940
I'm Zach Memos.

255
00:13:37.940 --> 00:13:38.720
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

256
00:13:38.720 --> 00:13:39.974
>> And we will see you soon.

257
00:13:39.974 --> 00:13:47.110
[MUSIC]

258
00:13:47.110 --> 00:13:51.687
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: Terry and Zach offer a quick refresher of key concepts and vocabulary of ITIL best practice.
episodes.title: Foundation Refresher

episodes.description: Terry and Zach reinforce the key considerations of customers, value, & service at the heart of ITSM considerations.
episodes.title: Key Concepts of ITIL

episodes.description: Terry and Zach continue to reinforce the key considerations of customers, value, & service at the heart of ITSM considerations, look at RACI charts-RACI matrix, Accountable Person compared to Responsible Person, Process Owners, Process Managers, Risk Management, Security Management, and the progression of Knowledge to Wisdom.
episodes.title: Key Concepts of ITIL Part 2

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a repeatable, holistic view to planning communications for four key stakeholder groups.
episodes.title: Communication and Stakeholder Management

episodes.description: Terry and Zach highlight the importance of integration & coordination across all five stages of the lifecycle.
episodes.title: A Focus on Integration

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a high-level review of the purpose and value of SS Processes.
episodes.title: Service Strategy Processes

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a high-level review of the purpose and value of SD processes.
episodes.title: Service Design Processes

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a high-level review of the purpose and value of the ST processes.
episodes.title: Service Transition Processes

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide a high-level review of the purpose and value of 'SO' processes.
episodes.title: Service Operation Processes

episodes.description: Terry and Zach explain why 'CSI' should be positioned throughout all stages of the lifecycle.
episodes.title: Universal Value of CSI

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide key points of interface and deliverables from 'SD.
episodes.title: Service Design Across the Lifecycle

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide key points of interface and deliverables from 'ST.
episodes.title: Service Transition Across the Lifecycle

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide key points of interface from 'SO,' 'CSI,' and other stages of the lifecycle.
episodes.title: Service Operation and CSI Across the Lifecycle

episodes.description: Terry and Zach review considerations of challenges and risks for each lifecycle stage.
episodes.title: Managing Success Across the Lifecycle

episodes.description: Terry and Zach review the importance of governance in making IT Service Management successful.
episodes.title: Governance Across the Lifecycle

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide focus on how organizational structure can help support IT Service Management.
episodes.title: Organization Across the Lifecycle

episodes.description: Terry and Zach review the alignment of Service Performance with business outcomes.
episodes.title: The Importance of Measurement

episodes.description: Terry and Zach provide overall guidance on implementing & improving IT Service Management capabilities.
episodes.title: Implementing and Improving ITSM

episodes.description: Terry and Zach review the first 4 questions from Sample Paper 1 with a focus on exam taking techniques.
episodes.title: Sample Paper Review

episodes.description: Terry and Zach review questions 5 through 10 from Sample Paper 1 with a focus on exam taking techniques.
episodes.title: Sample Paper Review Part 2
